results.title: Picture to post
results.creator_credit: Sarah Erulkar, John Durst and Rayant Pictures

results.title: Picture in your mind
results.creator_credit: Philip Stapp, Julien Bryan, International Film Foundation and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Philip Stapp’s sequel to “Boundary Lines” (001397), with a special score by Gene Forell. This film shows the background and growth of prejudice, from the dawn of mankind. It indicates the responsibility of the individual for a better world. Animated, inventive and evocative. Spoken by Walter Abel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Stapp, Julien Bryan, International Film Foundation and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Picture books on video. - Volume 3 = The gigantic balloon
results.creator_credit: Catharine Campbell, Cathy Miller and Video Classroom
results.brief_description: The award winning, Australian children’s stories on this video include “The Gigantic Balloon” by Ruth Park with illustrations by Kilmeny and Deborah Niland and narration by Robert Coleby, “The Tram to Bondi Beach” by Elizabeth Hathorn with illustrations by Julie Vivas and narration by Robert Coleby, and “My Grandmother Lived in Gooligulch” written and illustrated by Graeme Base with narration by Tim McKenzie.

results.title: Pictorial Parade No. 25. No random harvest
results.brief_description: New Zealand’s pine plantations, among the largest man-made forests in the world, are now producing the raw materials for timber and paper manufacture. New saw and paper mills have been built and existing plants enlarged. New railways and towns were also needed to service the industries created by this planned harvest of timber.
results.description: New Zealand’s pine plantations, among the largest man-made forests in the world, are now producing the raw materials for timber and paper manufacture. results.title: Picasso the sculptor
results.creator_credit: Roland Penrose and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Surveys the sculpture of Picasso from the early figurative heads of 1902-l903; the cubist constructions of 1912-l924; his carved and modelled figures of the 1930’s; his bronze assemblages and ceramic sculptures of the 1940’s and the 1950’s, to the sheet metal cut-outs of the sixties.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roland Penrose and Arts Council of Great Britain
